title: Very thankful for the service
body: My wife and I are so thankful for getting both vaccines. Friendly staff and well organised I would highly recommend

title: Great Care and Attention
body: Had Total Colectomy and was very impressed with the wonderful care and attention that I received from all of the staff. Pain control, with the help of the Pain Buster, was excellent. The atmosphere on the ward was cheerful and relaxed even at busy times. To have a room and bathroom to myself plus a wonderful view made such a difference to my mental wellbeing especially as I stayed for longer than expected. I felt very safe as measures for preventing Covid infection were strictly enforced.

title: Covid 19 Vaccine
body:
Brilliant practice.

We had our first dose of the C19 vaccine yesterday and the whole thing was incredibly smooth and efficient. The staff were very friendly and addressed all of my concerns and ensured I was OK before leaving. I felt very safe the entire time.

Would highly recommend this practice to everyone in the area. 

Thank you Trevelyan House!

author: Halstead Resident
title: Calls for an appointment met with difficulties
body:
Calls for an appointment at Elizabeth Courtauld surgery meet with immediate difficulties because of the way receptionists to respond.  
I sent information following a hospital admission. I was advised in writing to make a GP appointment via a telephone call. I put credit on my mobile phone and commenced the call in the afternoon. Waiting through automated messages took a long time; coronavirus information is essential however, this underlines the need for a profession process.  
I simply said, I had called to make an appointment but was immediately informed, there were no more appointments today, I would "have to" call back in the morning. I said, I could make an appointment for another day. This met with argument, and I said, even in the following month. This met with contempt: well, it will definitely be next month, certainly not yet. I said I would accept any appointment (this seemed awkward; I asked if they could get appointments on the screen? ) I had to listen while the receptionist hummed. ( I wondered privately how things would go if I hummed. )  
At last I was offered a GP call two weeks ahead and accepted. I sent details of this experience to the practice manager who said their interpretation of the recording was that I was treated calmly and politely! When I was a solicitor's PA/receptionist, I'd have been dismissed for similar behaviour. I think the team needs to shed their first line of defence mode, be impartial and reasonable. If a job role makes someone feel resentful, tempting them to be rude, then they must find something different.

author: dracoqb89
title: Birthing pools out of action
body:
I am very disappointed to hear that the birthing pools in Inverurie are STILL not fixed. They have been out of action since July 2020. I have my heart set on a water birth because I missed out on having one with my first born. Instead of going to my nearest maternity unit just 10mins away in Inverurie, I am now considering travelling 40mins to Peterhead maternity unit to get my water birth.  
It's not acceptable and a down right shame that parents and parents-to-be are having to do this. Too many people have been let down by this issue and it must be addressed.

author: l1991
title: Birthing pools
body: I’m due my first baby in summer 2021 and was really hoping for a water birth at Inverurie maternity unit, however all the birth pools are still out of commission and have been since summer 2020. I was advised work would have commenced before now and they’d be back in service by May, however it’s now April and work still hasn’t started on allowing the pools to be used again. This is really disappointing as it limits options for pregnant women to have the birth and experience they desire.

author: warmwr78
title: Misdiagnosed and sent home....
body:
I was recently hospitalised due to ongoing severe pelvic pains & abdominal pains.  
I was in hospital for a total of 4 days & in between i had a CT Scan & MRI Scan & to try and determine what the problem was.  
The CT Scan showed no abdominal problems so that's when the MRI was issued to rule out any pelvic problems as they said it looked like possible PID from the CT scan.  
The results from the MRI were then sent over to the gynaecology department to have a look and they said that they had came back all clear and the suspected PID was actually my ovaries ovulating?  
I was then able to go home the next day with the pains being put down to a bad IBS flare-up.  
Even though ive had IBS for years and never experienced anything like it.  
A week later i decided to still go to the original appointment made by my GP from months before for the Ultrasound to try and see what the problem was.I asked the nurse if the ultrasound was needed & she said it wouldnt be considering a week before i had just had to X2 scans done and they had came back ALL clear and my results would be the same from the other 2 scans but still to go ahead with the ultrasound considering im here.  
So i recieved my results back yesterday....  
And my GP is now saying it looks like i have PCOS and they have referred me back over to the gynaecologly department for more blood tests and to investigate further considering i had my bloods taking daily when i was in hospital & was just told a week prior i was all ok! Now am not??  
Coming home from hospital i changed my diet 360 to help with the IBS but the pelvic pain is still there every single day. And as well as another X-ray appointment next week for another health issue i am really at my wits end with it all , No wonder ive been put on antidepressants in the last week. i just dont understand how something like this could have been missed and put down to "bowel problems" when it was seamly so clear from a 2 second ultrasound that was done.  
Now i dont know what scan is right or wrong or whats went on!? I am glad i went with my gut and still went for the ultrasound as i wouldnt have been any the wiser to what is causing this pain.... :(

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

links.id: total lack of confidence in the process

author: lynxmx46
title: Stonebridge Centre
body:
I have been in crisis and feeling unsafe for several days now and each time I have been turned away by the mental health team.  
I feel that I am in need of seeing a psychiatrist, but instead I have an appointment with the same nurse who discharged me from the service! I don't feel comfortable with this.  
I feel let down by the mental health team and my health is getting worse.

author: disappointed-service-user
title: Staff member refused me
body: A staff member at the vaccination site, refused to give me the second dose of the Pfizer vaccination despite me receiving an appointment from my GP practice and showing up on time. According to this person I should wait 8 weeks after my first dose top get the second one when the official guidance itself says you can be called between 3 to 12 weeks. I took time during a holiday to get vaccinated to be arbitrarily prevented from getting the vaccine. I would not recommend anyone going to this centre and I feel I was treated unfairly. The staff who welcomed me were very friendly but unfortunately whether I got the vaccine or not was not guaranteed despite me following the rules. The Bocking street centre is excellent and I would recommend going to that one.

author: citizenclive
title: End-of-life care without a GP.
body:
A few weeks ago I comforted my Mum thru the night at the end of her life. As I quietly left the ward at 7.45am, the nurse gave me a bereavement leaflet & explained that I had been central for the end of life care team thru the night. Another nurse thanked me but no one walked me to my car, or asked me if I was ‘OK’ to drive home. I was the only visitor in the entire hospital [Royal Berkshire]. All pastoral services at the hospital were “closed until further notice”.  
I had looked after mum alone at home for five years but doing it at the end with GPs refusing to come out for 3 weeks - and then being barred from the hospital for a week until the terminal diagnosis came thru was not easy. I was able to do my bit for 3 days at the end. The final lone walk out of an 'abandoned' hospital at 7.45am was chilling. The whole experience has done my head in.  
A deadly game is being played between District nurses and GPs who I feel play pass the parcel. Using COVID as an excuse, GPs are refusing to come out and examine people in their homes. The game continues until the sufferer reaches the 999 stage. Paramedics then take over. In our case, the GP misdiagnosed the problem over the phone - as a steroid crisis - only an abdominal examination would have revealed blood clots in the lungs coming from terminal cancer.  
Mum passed away 10 days after the 999 event but we had been fobbed off by GPs for the previous 3 weeks. I had a district nurse on my driveway saying they were only here to look at the pressure sores, & not here to help with the breathing problems - this is the DN distancing herself from the GPs flawed diagnosis. I feel like the ambulance paramedics and district nurses and adult safeguarding people know what is happening.  
God help anyone else in this situation. The COVID virus has been allowed to eclipse other forms of suffering and terminal conditions. Cancer, heart disease, loneliness, dementia etc. Why ?

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Bergf56
title: Clinically vulnerable people like myself put at risk
body:
I firstly want to thank the staff in the minor injury unit for treating me in such a professional manor. I am not one to make complaints however my experience I felt it very important to share.  
I had hurt my ankle and rang for an appointment and was offered a morning appointment. As a cancer patient and other health problems, I am extremely clinical vulnerable and I was assured on the phone that the Dungannon Minor Injury Unit was appointment only and is never busy.  
When i arrived there was a queue of people and it was overcrowded. The seats in the hallway were full and there was no social distancing.  
I had to stand until I was called in.  
Many of the people arriving had no masks on.  
I felt very anxious and vulnerable.  
Overhearing conversations it turns out most of the other people arrived without an appointment, yet were not turned away and seen anyway.  
This is completely unacceptable. Vulnerable patients such as myself have been shielding all year. What is the point of an appointment system if anybody can just walk in as these people and seen anyway.  
When I raised this with staff I was told it is safer there than in a supermarket. I am not sure as the people walking in without appointments had no masks.  
I hope this is addressed so other extremely clinically vulnerable people like myself do not be put at risk.  
King Regards  
Bergf56

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: JDT
title: Sanitation for immuno-compromised patients
body:
I am so anxious as immunocompromised infected person.  
1 cleanliness. My room was cleaned nearly every day- did not involve washing the floor of the bedroom. The surfaces were not sanitized every day, clinical things fallen to the floor would be picked up by the cleaner and placed back for nurses to use- this involved IV tap covers. The windows are dusty inside. Dust and refuse blows up into the window from the filthy roof top space. Seagulls and pigeon fly around all day  
2. Infection control. I do not have my own single patient use BP cuff. Other patients are exposed after me. And I after them. The monitor is wheeled in and out. Not cleaned down before using with me or wiped after that I know of before moving to next person. I know this may affect timeliness  
3.Nurse / carer does not gel gloves before or after taking any personal observations. similarly many things like Drug lap top will be carried into my room and placed on the seat of my chair or bed - side chest. These areas have not been cleaned once in last few days at least. And certainly not the advertised 2 hourly  
4. Patients are not given hand wipes before and after meals. Just two insubstantial tissue like napkins. Cutlery does not come in a wrapper to demonstrate cleanliness. Who knows about plates? My drinking cup was changed for the first time in 8 days yesterday The water jug may be refilled. Not sure when they are collected properly washed at the correct temp and returned to patients. ? (Is all this multi patient use safe in time of Covid-19 and or immuno compromised patients (like me) or all people-  
I have contacted PALs the staff I have spoken to either say we are very busy with old people or say this is what we do.

author: Smiley Bees
title: Fracture clinic
body:
My 5 year old has broken her arm & we were called first thing and asked to attend clinic in Truro for a new cast, X-ray and assessment to see if surgery would be required the next day. We made the 3 hour round trip only for the doctor to say that the cast shouldn’t be changed for a week, that they can see the X-rays from the previous evening and generally talked to me in a dismissive tone as if I’d chosen to waste this person's time. This conversation could have been done via video or telephone and either way being kind in your tone and compassionate in your approach doesn’t cost a thing.  
Thankfully this was a stark contrast to the compassionate and kind approach taken at another hospital the evening before.

author: Lorraine63
title: Aspen Ward
body:
My elderly mother (85) who has Dementia and is visually impaired (nearly blind) was taken into A&E yesterday. She has not been in hospital since the 70's and in relatively in good health until this episode. I received regular updates from A&E but when she was moved to the ward NOTHING I have been calling for over a hour and half.  
I understand they are busy and that is not excuse, everyone is busy!! Its bad enough not being able to see my mum but not to get updates is appalling. Maybe it would be wise to implement a messaging system where the ward update 1 member of the family during the course of the day, if they are unable to use the phone.  
Just 1 update, that's all we ask for.

title: Efficient service provided.
body:
I attended on Monday 22/3/21 & was told that I can expect to be contacted to make arrangements for treatment within a few weeks. I was then contacted shortly afterwards when arrangements were made for the procedure o take place at another medical Centre last Friday, 26/3/21.
I attended in good time & heard from Health Harmonie, as I was previously told I would. The procedure was carried out quickly & efficiently & I was on my way home less than 30 minutes later.
I was assured that the only reason the procedure was carried out so quickly was availability of staff & not an urgent need for it to be done which reassured me.
I have had no other dealings with Health Harmonie but based upon my recent encounters with them would be happy to deal with them again.

author: Treacle3
title: The doctor gave excellent care
body:
Thank you to the ADOC team and nice doctor who came out to my mum recently in the middle of the night in Troon.  
I was really worried about my mum and the Doctor gave excellent care and reassurance to my mum and myself.  
We really appreciated your kindness and you really listened and cared .

author: Paul CH
title: Faultless
body: Really calm and relaxed, the process at the SSE arena was faultless, very slick and speedy.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Patientanon531
title: Communication could be improved
body:
Feedback - Communication from staff to patients could be improved.  
Context - I very rarely, if ever, have had to attend hospitals before so raising this poor experience for development and improvement opportunities for staff.  
I attended the UTC with a relatively minor injury in comparison to a number of other patients attending that day. However, I attended to confirm my injury didn't require stitches, further treatment beyond basic first aid and to get the best possible information to treat this at home (and therefore not adding to extra unnecessary footfall to A&E). Throughout my experience, the level of communication from multiple staff members was poor:  
- Was not advised of the current estimated triage/waiting time on arrival.  
- Was not triaged - mentioning this as I'm unsure if my injury required triage or not and if I did, then this should be recorded.  
- I felt repeatedly fobbed off when I expressed my concern at the waiting time (politely of course). For context, I fully appreciated how busy the centre was that day and knew to expect a fair wait. However, each time I requested an update for an approx waiting time after 90 minutes or so, I was told a different version of that I couldn't be waiting much longer or I was next yet watched numerous patients get called in before me. This was frustrating so I approached the desk again to ask for a realistic timescale so if I was told there would be a considerable wait e.g. another hour or two, I could have made an informed decision and sought medical advice/treatment elsewhere; rather than me sitting in UTC for 3 hours (arrived after 5pm, called in to be seen after 8pm).  
- The member of staff seeing/treating me did not introduce themselves (no idea whether they were a Nurse, GP or HCA).  
- Seeing me was rushed and they couldn't get me out the door quick enough which meant they failed to tell me how to appropriately treat my wound and what complications to watch out for once discharged e.g. infection signs. I had to repeatedly ask for this information which was unacceptable.  
I also had to request an additional bandage from staff working the front desk for another patient, as I could see droplets of blood starting to form through a makeshift bandage. I felt this should have been noticed and provided on their arrival. This patient ended up sitting there for a considerable length of time and could have ended up dripping blood on the waiting room floor.  
Reporting this as I felt standards could have been better on this occasion. Just a gentle reminder for staff to not let standards slip for lower priority patients please.

author: Greatful daughter
title: Overwhelmed by their kindness
body:
My beloved Mum was admitted to ward 3 last month as an emergency. We did not know, at that time, that we would lose her only three days later.  
I don’t have the words to praise the staff in this ward highly enough, especially Jenny and Hannah, who treated my Mum with so much loving care and respect, which I have not seen before in any other hospital. I was overwhelmed by their kindness towards me and my family, and kept us fully informed, about what was happening, and their sensitivity towards the unexpected nightmare we had found ourselves in. They are angels.

author: Coco21
title: My Dad - a virtual Easter Sunday family gathering
body:
Each year my parents host an Easter Sunday family gathering- after missing last year due to lockdown it was disappointing that due to my fathers admission to hospital that he wouldn't be at the head of the table.  
The video call service provided allowed us to see him and chat and hopefully that connection will help give him some comfort as we cannot visit - we feel its vital to make this connection to aid his recovery. As an elderly very independent man going into hospital was a difficult thing to accept as he has lost his ability to be independent and we hope that some of that independence can be worked towards if we can connect with him and of course with all the great work the hospital staff do each day to aid his recovery.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Ja81
title: Well looked after
body:
During being a patient in the hospital which I already put a report in about how I could not fault any member of staff or department or ward I was in I would like now to praise the Endoscopy team.  
I had an Endoscopy done as an in patient I was very afraid of having this done but from arriving at the theatre I was cared for by the nursing staff and well looked after. The doctor explained everything to me and after numbing my throat with the spray gave me a sedative. Six biopsies were taken and I can honestly say I do no remember anything of the test at all I would never be afraid if I needed this test done again .I have not had the results yet was told I would be written to with them I know it takes a while for the results it will be four weeks coming since test was done can anyone tell me roughly how long it takes.

links.id: fully supported by the whole team

author: Spence21
title: Covid Vaccine Centre
body: The centre was very well organised. In and out within 30 minutes including the 15 minutes that you have to wait after your vaccine.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: RelativeABC
title: Communication and follow up
body:
My mum was admitted with acute onset of confusion and brought in by ambulance to FVRH. She was subsequently treated for a UTI and discharged the following day.  
Due to Covid restrictions I was unable to accompany my mum to hospital therefore relied on staff keeping me updated. She was admitted in the evening and I called a few hours later and was updated over the telephone, being told that she was being kept in overnight and that they had started oral antibiotics. I was reassured that she was fairly settled and didn’t appear to be confused. The following morning I contacted the department for an update and managed to speak to the frailty nurse. As my mum had improved and was on the correct treatment it was agreed that she could be discharged later that day after being seen by physios. I was informed that I would be contacted as to when to collect her. This was early afternoon. A few hours later I called the ward for an update to be told she was in the ward discharge area but that they would check she was good to go and they would call me back. I ended up calling again 1.5 hours later to be told to come and collect my mother.  
On collecting my mum I realised she had indeed been waiting approx 3 hours for me to collect her but no contact had been made to organise this. I asked if there was anything else I needed to know and was told that the nurse looking after my mum had just met her and hadn’t been given a handover. I didn’t receive a discharge letter so left with the knowledge that the antibiotics were the only treatment needed. She was discharged home that night with the Hospital at Home team following up her care.  
The Hospital at home team visited my mum the following day and I was asked by the doctor if we had received the prescription of magnesium and folic acid tablets that were being taxied out. This was the first I had been told that my mum’s magnesium Levels were low. I was given a prescription which I went and collected. The medicines that were meant to be getting taxied out never appeared. My mum’s care was covered by hospital at home service over the weekend with them visiting daily the first 3 days.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: ThatGeorgina
title: Dads care during his illness
body:
My Dad attended his GP in in late 2020 with pains in his back after moving a heavy object. They diagnosed muscular strain and Dad was happy with that. A number of weeks later, the pain had not subsided and he started to pee blood. He went back to his GP who ran a series of blood tests (that came back completely normal) checked his prostate (again, normal) and sent him for a scan of his kidneys, he got the results back the very same day.  
On the day Dr Senior told my dad that he suspected a suspicious mass in his kidney, he left my dad feeling heard, respected and above all, safe in the knowledge that he was going to do everything in his power to help. Dad said he felt like Dr Senior was his own private physician.  
Dad had been diagnosed a few weeks later with poorly differentiated renal carcinoma diagnosed at the Beatson in Glasgow - they suspected CDC was the cause, a very rare and highly aggressive cancer. Within a few weeks my dad had metatastatic spread in his liver, hip bone, lung and spine. The latter paralysed him from the chest down. Dr Senior called the ward he was on on a number of occasions to speak with his oncologist Dr Garcia. When we got Dad home after great efforts put in place by the whole Beatson team, Dr Senior and the East Kilbride DN’s, Dr Senior visited a number of times to ensure his palliative care was in place well. He took innumerable phone calls from my sister and I while we endeavoured to ensure my dad was comfortable.  
My parents have attended the same GP surgery in all of its incarnations since the 1970’s - I’ve never heard my Dad heap so much praise on a single GP from that practice as he did for Dr Senior. He said “he’s special, there’s not many people like him in the world, never mind doctors”. My family have been comforted by a man we hardly know at the most devastating point in our lives. Dad passed away on 30th March. He wasn’t scared, and knew that all that could have been done, had. Dr Senior removed fear from a dying man, and anger from a grieving family and we will be forever in his debt.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
MASScot- Melanoma Action and Support Scotland

author: izargm96
title: Excellent efficiency and service at SSE arena
body:
Well done to everyone involved. From the car park attendants, the check in and medical staff. So proud of the NHS. the attention to detail is phenomenal. Even playing music and everyone is friendly and helpful.  
You’ve made a surreal situation very relaxed and efficient. This is the NHS at its very best. Hats off to you all. Well done.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Samoshack2
title: No one answering calls or messages
body:
I have contacted the number on the fatigue management group on 01698 366421  
I have let a message and phone in many occasions with no answer.

author: giraffeww84
title: 1st vaccine in SSE Arena Belfast
body:
Very organized set up, friendly staff from the Marshall's to NHS nurses and orderlies.
Queues kept moving.
Thanks for your care!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Awful,just awful
body:
What a disgraceful surgery,to the point myself and my partner have left. I can't believe the difference between the surgery I am at now,professional and efficient to how Wheatfield is.
Someone in the reception is rude and has I dont care attitude.!When I can actually get through I spend 30mins just on hold waiting to speak to someone and then you have to tell them what your issue is,so I explained I had found a lump in my breast,but was told I will get a call from a Dr in 4 weeks,what a joke. I'm pretty sure something like this is not something to just be left,I asked about this and was told just to wait  or just wait or try again in the morning,nothing was checked to see if something else could be done
When I eventually got seen for my smear appointment, 3 months after my initial letter came,which I acted on straight away, I informed the nurse about the lump and she even said that's something that should of not just been left, she actually went to a dr who then saw me.Finally someone who cares.
The reception need to realise that people are generally calling the surgery as they have a concern and are worried about something and a little empathy would go a long way,people don't need a rude unhelpful person on the other line.The wait is a joke as it is but to then be greeted by a rude receptionist on the other end,really is infuriating. 
I emailed the surgery about the whole number of issue I have had and was told this had been passed over to the practice manager and  would be in touch.Surprise,still waiting for this call
This surgery and the manager really need looking into, to be representing the NHS in such a

title: Very Unfair
body: After waiting many months, I was assigned eventually to a CBT therapist for three months. The treatment was not effective and didn't help me. Therefore, the threapist directed me to the counselling service. I did one phone assessment with a counsellor and by the end of the call, I was told that I need long-term treatment as my condition is severe, and because of that, they can NOT help and I need to go private! I find this practice is wrong and unfair. The idea that if you have a severe mental health condition or you need a long-term treatment then the NHS can not help (at least based on Ealing IAPT) is completely wrong and illogical!!

title: Emergency appointment
body: Wanted an emergency appointment - when I had waited after 20 in the queue before me was answered by an unhelpful receptionist. Was very rude and unhelpful and stressed. Eventually she put the phone down.  Had another call 30 mins later by another female.  Had to explain the whole symptoms again - could tell she didn't want me to have an appointment because they were so busy and full up.  She was so stressed as well and jumped down my throat.  I pushed and got an appointment 2 days later.  I was really upset after this - I am an older lady and shouldn't be spoken to like this.  (I know the surgery is very busy - too many patients - but if staff could try and be a bit more understanding to everyone then your patients would be alot  happier).  At least I saw a nice Dr who approved me having an appointment.

title: Fantastic, professional practice
body:
Having a pre-existing condition (Crohn's) is difficult at the best of times, but AMC have been fabulous despite the difficulties of Covid. The staff are hard working and professional, and clearly take a lot of pride in ensuring we get the medical support we need. The work on rolling out vaccines has been particularly impressive.

Fantastic service from all!

author: kilorn89
title: COVID vaccine SSE Arena
body:
Very well organised
Nurses were so helpful
Felt reassured

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Farhan
title: Being tested COVID positive
body: I have recently been tested COVID positive. Got a sms advising to isolate with the immediate family immediately. To my surprise it has been about 30 hours and no body from NHS has contacted to to check my health condition. Quiet strange for me as this being a contiguous disease I am expected to stay at home my understanding is that NHS should contact me or guide me the way forward rather than just working on the numbers.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: composermw58
title: SSE Covid Vaccination Centre
body: I got my vaccination at the SSE Arena, Belfast. All the staff were class! Friendly, reassuring and very helpful... they were exceptionally well drilled and the whole experience was straightforward because of all the wonderful staff... from the guys directing traffic, people on entrance duty and guiding us, admin staff, to the nurses and cleaning staff... Thank you everyone for taking the stress out of what could have been a worrying experience!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: LJB2010
title: Day case admission for my 8 year old son to have teeth removed
body: At the beginning of April 2021 my 8 year old son was admitted to the Outwood Ward at East Surrey Hospital for a day case admission to have several teeth removed. Every single member of staff we encountered during our stay was wonderful and made my son and myself feel at ease for the entire time we were there. From the nurse who took us to and from theatre, to the nurse who got me a well needed cup of coffee after my son went to theatre, to the nurse who discharged us who explained that she had asked the theatre staff to provide some more pain relief as two children had come out of theatre distressed and in pain while we were waiting to go to theatre ourselves. Thank you to everyone who looked after us during our short visit, I wish I could remember your names but you made our visit go off without a hitch!

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

author: woodpigeonzh87
title: Two recent visits to Lincoln ULHT
body:
Visit number 1 :- Copy of letter sent to Mr Morgan CEO  
I am writing in the hope that you will express my personal thanks and gratitude to those members of the dermatology team (Dr Kopcsanyi & Nurse Steph) who carried out the procedure on my right ear one day mid March 2021. I realise that I am somewhat slow in expressing my thanks but I think it’s probably an age thing!  
The whole experience was exceptionally good from the video consultation to the actual procedure. All of this was carried out with care, consideration and compassion and I believe truly defines the way that the hospital is run. Everything was explained in detail and Dr Kopcsanyi went to great lengths to ensure I fully understood all that would happen and ensured that I was quite happy with what was about to take place. The whole procedure went like clockwork and I should have expressed my thanks at that time but believe that I missed that opportunity. Please let the team know how deeply grateful I am for their care and skill and that I am so sorry I failed to express it at the time.  
I believe that Lincoln UHT have gone (and are continuing to go) to great lengths to employ really caring staff and to improve services to patients. Personally I commend the use of video and telephone consultations - I found it far less stressful and time consuming and the net result was a patient who felt the whole process concentrated on the patient and not on standard procedure.  
Visit number 2:- Grantham Hospital (MRI Scan)  
Beginning of April 2021  
After all the 'flack' that Lincoln ULHT have suffered over the last few years, I have to report that yet again they've more than lived up to my expectations/requirements. My visit to Grantham for an MRI scan was enhanced by the staff friendliness/helpfulness and very high standard of cleanliness! No waiting, no messing about, professionally handled and as I currently have mobility problems these were extremely well catered for by staff who actually care - from the kind gentleman 'on the door' of Tower block to the MRI staff who didn't leave me struggling at the end but took me right up to the Car Parking machine! Unbelievable in this day and age and I fail to understand as a member of the public what has gone so wrong that they need 'special measures' - I think a little more recognition for the excellent and kindly service they provide - with good cheer and a smile too! Long gone are my experiences of the 1980's when I spent time arguing with a Consultant because he was unable to understand the GP's handwriting and didn't wish to believe that I knew why I was there!!!!!!  
Congratulations to a caring, kind and considerate workforce which really deserves greater appreciation.

author: Lynne G
title: Experience of A&E
body: I visited on Friday evening and was recalled on Monday morning.   On both occasions, all staff were lovely - couldn't have been kinder.   On Friday, I witnessed nurses, doctors and porters dealing with a number of challenging individuals.   They did so with patience, calmness and care, always treating these individuals with dignity. I've visited other A& E departments previously,   and have sometimes felt like I was on a conveyor belt. This has not been my experience here - I felt looked after in the whole, by people with good humour and kindness,   working in difficult circumstances. My heartfelt thanks to all.

author: keano
title: Appointment at Dermatology Clinic
body: Taken very promptly on arrival by David - procedure explained clearly and made to feel at ease. Ildiko prepared the area and Adrian was also in attendance. All staff very welcoming and efficient.

author: Jabbed
title: Covid Vaccine
body: I had my vaccine today in the SSE Arena in Belfast.   The organisation was first class. The stewards were helpful and professional.   The medical staff were excellent. The injection itself was not just painless, for a moment I doubted whether or not it had happened! I am delighted. Now I am pretending to be very lightheaded and woozy so I don't have to do some jobs in the house. In truth my arm feels a little heavy. That is all.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: stonewe95
title: Covid vaccination
body: I had my first jab today at the SSE Arena in Belfast, and the staff there made the entire experience completely painless. All staff I was in contact with were so helpful and approachable. I walk with a stick and, having queued for a time, I was leaning a bit heavily on it. One of the staff passing noticed this straight away and offered me a chair, then came back to me to move me to the head of the queue. The thoughtfulness and care in this were typical of my experience today. Everything was fully explained about the vaccine and the vaccination program, and each step of my injection and possible side-effects was made clear. I am very grateful to all the staff at the Vaccine Centre for their help, care and attention.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Very Organised
body: I had both of my COVID vaccines at this surgery and the experience was very good both times. Very well organised, clearly as COVID-safe as possible, and generally very positive. Keep up the good work!

title: A great Practice
body:
Having been a patient at this practice since 1976, 
I was delighted to receive my invitation to have my Pfizer covid vaccinations provided at the surgery on16th January  and 3rd April 2021 respectively. The whole procedure was  extremely well organised on both occasions from the volunteers 
welcoming us into the car park , right through to the painless inoculation jabs and friendly aftercare check.  Five stars, to everyone involved ! ( But then, that is the standard of care
  Whitley  Surgery has always provided)

title: Absolutely fabulous
body: Linfoot Ward - cannot be faulted. Cared for my husband between 2.1.21 to 12.2.21.  Their empathy, care and patience was second to none. He felt safe and cared for and I was completely comfortable speaking with them knowing they took everything on board and had his best interests at heart. They treated him as a human being and not a number and the standard of care from top to bottom was exemplary. Shame the same cannot be said about the general wards and lack of communication at the John Radcliffe.

title: Excellent
body: A brilliant service, giving vital medical care when GP surgeries are closed. I dropped in late on a Bank Holiday and the Doctor gave excellent advice and prescribed the tablets I needed. The staff are superb

title: Brilliant Walk in Emergency A & E
body: I attended on Sat afternoon it was busy with many injured or Ill people but 3 hours later hobbled out on crutches after seeing 2 very experienced and brilliant nurses and having had an Xray. They cleaned up my cut and stitched me up excellent service I will return but not too often I hope.

readBy.name: Hounslow and Richmond Community Healthcare NHS Trust

author: waltzyj33
title: My mums hospital stay in the Forth Valley Royal Hospital – ICU and Ward 11B
body:
Mum was admitted with pancreatitis at the end of February. After a week or so she was getting worse and started to develop delirium, this resulted in her being sedated and ventilated into the ICU. She remained there for around a week and half. Her condition was critical. The staff at the ICU were amazing. I had sent in some music for her on an MPS player and they ensured it was played. I emailed them photos that they printed and put around her bed. At the beginning she was too sick to speak, we were calling the ward 3 times a day and spoke to many of the staff on rotation. They were always highly professional, understanding and informative, even when we could tell they were very busy. When she was a bit better we video called her daily. They were excellent at facilitating this.  
We understand the extra pressure that COVID puts on the staff, caring for mum and also being our only information source. It must be alot of pressure describing the situation to loved ones with no medical understanding, when we are unable to visit to see us with our own eyes. The were fantastic.  
Unfortunately we cant remember their names, but every nurse we spoke to was great and we would like to thank them. Mum is coming home tomorrow after a number of weeks recovering on the ward. Heartfelt thanks for all the staff for facilitating her recovery and supporting us along the way.  
After spending almost 2 weeks in ICU on a ventilator with pancreatitis, my mother was admitted to surgical ward 11B. Her doctor was Miss Cannings and the Charge nurse was Chris. She was very ill and soon diagnosed with delirium. We called the hospital to speak to her 3 times a day and the staff were excellent at facilitating this, even though at times we could tell they were very busy.  
To treat the delirium, Chris was able to override the COVID restrictions to allow my father to visit. He visited daily and always reported positive interactions with the staff. I had recently returned from overseas where I was working and had 3 negative covid tests and fresh out of Isolation. After requesting visitation I was granted this. The daily visits were getting a bit much for dad and I knew that contact with me would help mum. I cant thank Chris and his staff enough (there was an acting charge nurse, whose name I cant remember who was a key player in this too), this decision didn't have to be taken and it helped mum massively and also us. Me and dad did alternate visits for around 2 weeks. My experience with the staff was fantastic, I met many of the nurses in charge of mum and unfortunately cannot remember all of their names. They were always on hand to help, even at times being very busy. Any questions I had were answered and they really helped me to understand mums condition and how I could help. Chris gave me some of his time when I requested so I could raise some questions I had, he was highly professional and reassuring.  
The student nurses on the ward were brilliant, they were very professional, kind, caring and mum was delighted with them. I contacted Miss Cannings with some concerns about halfway through mums stay and she gave me time too, in a clearly very busy schedule. I was highly impressed with how knowledgeable she was about mums journey, from before ICU. She was caring and kind, I had explained to her that my dad was struggling with some things and she said all the right things to reassure him on the phone. This goes the same for the active charge nurse (whos name I cannot remember). There was some concerns that dad had, more a family issues with mums sister calling the hospital, I asked her to reassure him that her calls were not a problem, which she did and the situation was calmed.  
The care mum received has be really great, also the support the family has had. In these very tricky times with COVID, I am very grateful and full of respect for all the staff. Mum is coming home tomorrow to start her recovery here. A big thank you from us and mum!

author: pyxisfc55
title: Pick up/drop off
body: I am a regular visitor at Crosshouse hospital and in the drop off/pick up carpark there is a car permanently parked in 1 of the 3 non mobility spaces leaving only 2 available. This car is there all day. Can't understand why as it is surely a staff member who should be parking like everybody else in the main car park.

author: N777ART
title: Admitted for tests
body:
Dear Sirs,  
I want to acknowledge the extraordinary level of care I received from the all the nursing staff who attended to me during my recent stay at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary. I particularly want to mention Craig in Ward 103 who has to be one of the most considerate, devoted and calming nurses who I've ever encountered. Being in the hospital with an unknown condition can be a scary time and Craig always made me feel confident that I was in good hands. It was nice feeling assured that I'd be taken care of when I had needs. He never made me feel like a burden in spite of his obviously huge daily workload. Craig is a genuinely caring nurse who took time to talk with me and share his positivity and encouragement, which gave me some additional strength to deal with the uncertainty of my condition and the test and treatments I was receiving. He has a great big heart for the work he does and for the people he helps and it is clear that he is committed to pursuing nursing as a vocation - not merely his job.  
Please accept my deepest thanks

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Office of Stewart Stevenson, MSP for Banffshire and Buchan Coast

author: Bugsy Boy
title: Vaccine at the SSE Arena
body: The best performance I’ve ever seen at the Odyssey! ! What a band. From directions in the car park, to greeting, check in, injection and check out, like clockwork. Everyone efficient, welcoming and positive. Brilliant work from all involved. Your efforts are greatly appreciated.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: CGNI
title: SSE Arena Covid Vaccination programme
body: An extremely efficient service.   Well organised, plenty of staff, clear instructions, professionally managed.   I was very impressed.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: JaJ21
title: Poor medical care
body:
My Partner was admitted into hospital & was going to be dismissed 2 weeks later. They did find blood clots & confirmed an under active Thyroid, but after seeing 10 different Consultants they were going to send him home without any diagnosis of his muscle issues, which he was originally admitted for.  
Physiology refused to allow him to leave, but they could not assist him until they knew what was wrong. Now we are over six months later & still none the wiser. We have requested a genetics & genomics test but keep being informed they don’t need to do this as they can find any hereditary illnesses through blood tests. Blood test will only show what is being looked for, if you are unaware of what is medically wrong then blood tests will not help.  
Rheumatology suggested a steroid, which he never received, instead was prescribed a different steroid & this masked the issue with the muscle problem & Rheumatology dismissed him from their clinic. He was referred back 8 times to Rheumatology who stated it was nothing to do with them.  
After contacting PALS Rheumatology has admitted they prescribed the steroid which did mask the issue & thought the problem was with the thyroid.  
Since January he has had 3 seizures, after the second one we were advised it was a mini-stroke. We have since been advised by other departments that it was not a stroke but no answer to what happened.  
Today he had his third seizure, he was taken to Derriford hospital once again. He has now been dismissed & told they are unsure what the problem is & they will book him in for a MRI & prescribed him medication.  
Why can the MRI not be done whilst he is ill & how can you prescribe drugs for something you are unsure what it is? They also sent him home with the Cannula still in his arm.  
We have now had enough of the Doctors at Derriford, we feel they are not doing their jobs properly & keep passing the buck. If they are unsure then involve someone who may be able to assist rather than dismissing patients.  
We are very annoyed, angry & upset with the way we have been treated.

readBy.name: Plymouth University Urgent and Emergency Care Bsc (2020)

author: ariesps74
title: Guidance on support
body:
Lucy & Frankie visited me a few times & gave me guidance & support on sleeping, I enjoyed the visits. Lucy was always happy and talkative.  
:)

title: shocking
body:
I am deeply shocked and disappointed that after being on the waiting list for TWO YEARS to receive therapy I was discharged from this service and then 'didn't meet the criteria' for the adult mental health team. Being suicidal apparently isn't enough to get therapy in norfolk. I am very distraught about this - I have been waiting for a service that probably doesn't exist. I've been left hung out to dry with no help at all 

But this isn't just my story nobody in norfolk can find good mental health care due to cuts. My gp has made fun of people and been callous and cruel also. I feel so sorry for people in norfolk it seems if you're mentally ill to get any help anywhere you'd probably have to leave to county. 

Something needs to desperately change because it is totally sickeningly awful I have been left with no help at all after two years

i'd advise moving to another part of the UK if you want any help and never ever contact this service

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Vaccine
body: Had my first and second covid vaccine, really friendly and relaxed staff they  did an amazing job to make you feel safe and well looked after. Explained any side effects you might have and what to do, great service

title: Very helpful
body: I had problems with my mobile phone and didn’t know if information was getting through. I used the contact service and had reply very quickly, this helped at was a very stressful time so a very big thank you.

title: COVID Vaccination
body: Brilliantly organised from the moment the text was received advising i could book a vaccine. Easy to do, always kept informed and the service on the day was superb. Efficient, speedy and very safe. Thank you

title: Prompt, kind and efficient
body: Within an hour of completing an online consultation form and submitting photos to the practice, I was contacted by the doctor. A further telephone consultation took place, advise given and a prescription submitted to our local pharmacy. Couldn’t have wished or expected better treatment.

title: Excellent service
body: Receptionist listened carefully and informed the doctor of my problem.  The doctor decided, on examination, that I needed a referral to East Surrey Hospital. I am now awaiting an appointment.

title: Brilliant treatment from all the staff
body: Called 999 chest pain ambulance arrived within minutes the two crew very professional and caring . Taken to hospital were the same level of service continued everything was explained to me and felt safe and and in good hands can't fault anything Big thanks to all involved

readBy.name: East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust

title: Exceptional Care and Professionalism
body: Left hospital last week after hip revision surgery and so far from the first moment I staggered into Wrightington to now I have been amazingly impressed with everyone I've met.  I cannt praise strongly enough the care and support I have received.  A jewel in the NHS crown.

readBy.name: Wrightington, Wigan and Leigh NHS Trust

title: Complete admiration
body: This was my 2nd visit and like the first it was extremely efficient and well managed. The injection was painless and everybody so polite. Thank you all.

title: Good Service
body: A brilliant service by all staff in this surgery.  Thank you for always going above and beyond with all your help with my treatment, appointments and healthcare.

title: Excellent practice
body: My experience with the surgery has always been very positive. The doctor always listens and understands my health issues and advises accordingly. I have had a excellent experience and is definitely the best practice that I every been registered with. I would recommend them to all family and friends. Never had a problem with getting an appointment or speaking to a nurse or doctor.

title: Help, understanding & perseverance by member of…
body: The Covid Vaccination process is a massive logistical task but the member of staff responsible for co-ordination & liaison has been most helpful, understanding and provided great perseverance in assisting us with a successful outcome that has been a difficult challenge because of personal needs. As a family we are most grateful and appreciative.

title: Worst Experience of my Life!!!
body: I know I should have done this a year back when I had given birth at the birthing centre at QE but looking after a newborn and then the pandemic hit us I didn’t bother. Honestly the experience I had still haunts me to this day. I actually booked the birthing centre after the induction which made it sound like heaven on earth. I was told there will be two midwives available at all times. If needed we can be transferred to the normal ward in few minutes.This actually gave me confidence to go for the natural birth and choose the birthing centre.I waited at home for my contractions to get stronger, they were only few minutes apart so I decided to get to the hospital after calling them first and I was told to come in immediately.I got there with my husband and signed in at the reception this was around 10pm on the 30/11/2019. We were told to wait even though there was no one in-front us waiting and the waiting area was  completely empty.Anyways after half an hour when the pain got unbearable I was told to go to a room right infront of the reception area and wait there and a midwife will be there soon to check me. I literally had to wait another half hour or so and I felt as if I was going to give birth there and then. Finally she appeared and by that time I had water and blood running down my legs. She told me to lay down so she could measure how far dilated I was but I was in so much pain by then I couldn’t even sit still I managed somehow. After the check she told me to wrap a sheet around to cover and walk to the birthing room. By this time I could hardly walk and was screaming in pain. I told her she needs to shift me to the normal ward as I would like go for an epidural. I wasn’t dilated much 3/4 cm by then. This midwife completely ignored my plea left me screaming with my husband and just disappeared. After about half an hour I had more blood coming down my legs I couldn’t even stand. I was just sitting on the floor and felt like the baby was pushing down very hard. My husband looked and could see the baby’s head. He was so shocked and didn’t know what to do as he couldn’t leave me alone incase the baby just popped out. He started screaming and calling for help and the same midwife came and tried to put me on the bed which was too late I gave birth on the floor without any sheets and she caught the baby.I was treated like an animal and I feel so upset and angry every time the memories come back. I had no midwife attending to my needs since I got to the hospital I almost gave birth to my son on the floor. After this she left saying she will come back and clean the floor as there was blood everywhere and give me some pain killers but I never saw her again. My husband said she is too busy filling out the forms in my notes sitting outside obviously doing her job. Just pathetic I am scared for life and I wouldn’t wish that upon anyone. Please stay away from the maternity services of this hospital. This midwife was a disgrace to her profession!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Good Practise
body: We have been with this surgery 18years and have never had a problem with it. From receptionists to doctors I have always found them helpful and efficient. Yes, you don’t always see the same doctor but this is the case in most surgeries now, especially if you book an emergency appointment. We would have no problem recommending this surgery.

author: Ollie boy
title: My fiancé was in craigavon hospital
body: My fiancé was admitted to craigavon area hospital and was treated very well from the moment he arrived untill he was discharged.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Lanticbay
title: Brilliant nurses at Royal Cornwall Hospital
body: Nurses were brilliant. They put me at ease before during and after the procedure they made sure I understood what was going to happen and ensured I was comfortable. Louise performed the colonoscopy with Debbie and Anne also in attendance helping. Every body helped me cope with procedure. Thank you.

title: Appointment clarification
body: I received an appointment via text message for a specified appointment time at the surgery. I arrived 10 mins early to be told I would be acknowledged have having arrived for my appointment. I was waiting half an hour and when I prompted staff I was told it was a telephone appointment and I should not have come to the surgery. The text definitely said a surgery appointment. This is disorganisation and should be addressed. It is not appropriate to mistakingly send somebody to the surgery who is unwell and to put them at risk of exposure to others in a pandemic (ie. people sat in waiting area not wearing masks and not being told to wear them) when it is not necessary. When appointments are given out they should clearly state telephone appointment.

title: Extremely Rude Receptionists, No appointments!
body: I have been registered with this GP for over 18years and the receptionist service or lack of it has progressively got unbelievably worst.. I have tried for 3 weeks now to get an appointment but to no avail. Why the receptionist feel the need to ask you why you want to see the GP baffles me, as they are not medically qualified non are they the GP.. We are told appointments can only be booked on the day and must call from 08:30, but, when you call the phone is either busy, rings out and or told there are no appointments when you finally get to speak to the very rude receptionist. In all my years with this GP, I can count on one hand how many times I have actually gone in to see a GP in this surgery, as an NHS staff myself for over 15 years now, I am so fortunate to be working in a hospital that the surgeons, doctors are so accommodating that you can talk to them about any medical concerns & to say I feel embarrassed that these  Balmoral Gardens Red suites receptionists are part of the NHS family is an understatement.. They are a very bad example of what is it to be part of the NHS staff.. Why is is almost impossible to get an appointment and you do not have to be rude, let alone extremely rude to do your job, people call the surgery because they need to and are anxious, so you should be civil, professional and empathic to the callers/patients/clients.. We are all taxpayers, well, most of the calls are.. This is a public service, so be respectful of that fact..

title: extremely disappointed
body: I rang the surgery today (29th March) at 10.05am to book an appointment after receiving an email from the GP telling me to do so - to discuss a form that had been sent to me in the post that I had filled out. The receptionist told me she didn't understand at first but then after I explained again, she told me there were no appointments available today and that I would possibly have to ring back tomorrow but she would check with her supervisor, she came back telling me that she could book me in for a telephone appointment but only on the 20th April! 3 weeks away! I asked why it was so far away and she said that the pre-bookable appointments can be anywhere from a couple of days to 4 weeks away and that because her supervisor had told her it wasn't urgent, that the 20th was all she could give me. I was shocked! firstly I had already spent 17minutes on the phone trying to get through - listening to the awful hold music and a woman's voice telling me my call was important - clearly not if it takes that long to answer! and now being told that I am not urgent enough to get an earlier appointment. I can understand how busy the surgery is, but I do not think anyone should be having to wait so long for an appointment, I would not be asking for one, if I myself did not think that it was urgent. I feel incredibly let down in a service that is supposed to be there to help and care for people.

title: Contact
body: Why does the Practice leave the phone off the hook? There should always be access to the surgery during opening hours and if it's not open, a message left for Patients. Patients should always know they're in a queue to be answered, even if there's no appointments left the phone should be answered. Not to do so is extremely frustrating for patients and could be putting some in danger. Please answer the phone!

title: It is sad to see how this surgery gone downhill
body:
I remember the times when it was a well run and very popular surgery. Unfortunately it has become muddled up and remote.
Just some examples,letters from hospitals lost and when found not always acted upon. The result of a test was lost or never arrived, I shall never know,nobody noticed, nobody chased it up. List of repeat prescriptions suddenly changed without any medical reason or explanation, then changed back.

Of course I have tried to sort it out directly with the surgery but direct  no longer exists,eConsult squeezed it out. It is a long confusing form and if you manage to fill it there is the promise that somebody will phone within a day or so.
 Most but not all the time somebody phones but it is always a different person while their website says:Try to stick to the Doctor who knows you or your problem best. How can I stick to the same doctor when I have no choice of who is going to call?
Sometimes instead of a call I got a  no-reply email or message, most recently they even started to use template responses. It is getting to look  more like a faceless business than  a group of family doctors.

It is such a pity.

title: A positive experience
body:
It took a few weeks to be assessed by a wonderful lady who left me fairly optimistic. It was a long conversation and I felt she genuinely cared. 

Then there was a wait of a few months.

The CBT was six half-hour phone calls from one of the kindest people I’ve spoken to in decades and she allowed to get some things that have been bugging me for years off my chest. Also, with the help of my doctor, she got me off anti-depressants. 

Sadly, my depression score didn’t improve - which made me feel I’d let her down. I have taken to heart the idea of putting on a facade and acting happy with the hope that it’ll break the cycle, although this seems to just make things build up.

I was then passed to a smart woman for DIT. After one session she said my problems were too long standing and complex for her (that might be code for something). She passed me on to someone else.

Finally, I was assessed by a woman who believed in supernatural entities and demonic possession. While she was sympathetic I decided at this point IAPT wasn’t for me. I received a letter explaining that I’d been discharged from their services.

I suppose my feeling is I know I’m messed up and I won’t get better, but at least I tried - and on the plus side I talked with some caring people. 

Sadly I have a mental block when it comes to praying mental illness away. Maybe if you’re more of a spiritual person this service might be for you.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

title: Used to be ok , now terrible
body: You never speak or see the same doctor twice, there  is no follow up or review, impossible to get an appointment.  Reception staff are generally of a low quality and unhelpful and unfriendly.  I was handed class c medication with little follow up, care or explanation . Very slow off the mark with the vaccine appointment

title: Unacceptable
body: Waited 8 and a half hours for a callback for a child with a recurring ear infection, severe pain, swelling and leaking fluid from ears. Told usual practice was face to face appointment but none available. Have to wait until tomorrow to collect prescription as no information on pharmacy’s open on bank holidays. Told to see My own GP but impossible as can never get an appointment and my GP recommends calling 111!. I know the NHS is under pressure due to COVID but this is unacceptable

author: homamyq55
title: Ectopic pregnancy
body:
I want to thank all the wonderful people that helped me before and after my surgery in Craigavon Hospital for an ectopic pregnancy.  
The nurses on ward 4 South; Krystina, Paula, Isabella and Blaithin were amazing- they took great care of me and were always so kind when doing so. Particularly Blaithin chatted with me when I was feeling pretty low after surgery and made a huge effort to chase up paperwork so that I could be discharged, I really appreciated that.  
I'm incredibly grateful to Dr Finnegan, who went out of her way to call me in for a scan after hours after seeing my blood test results. She took great care of me when I found myself in a lot of shock after learning I needed to go to Craigavon for surgery and I really appreciated the time she took to explain what was happening and help me feel safe in a very overwhelming situation. The after care I had from Dr Finnegan and the rest of Craigavon EPU staff was incredible; I felt they were really thorough and very accessible for any concerns I had. Any time I called they were fantastic at getting back to me and I was never made to feel like an annoyance, I really felt they were always there for me which helped so much in my recovery. Mostly I just appreciated their kindness and felt they really understood how difficult everything had been, it was nice to feel that was always acknowledged. I really can't thank the EPU enough or think more highly of the people working there, they really helped me through such a difficult time.  
I really appreciate the NHS so much after my experience. I feel really lucky to have had access to such great life saving care when I needed it, and I'm so grateful to all the people working so hard to make that continue throughout the pandemic- thank you.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Not good enough W21& LTHTR
body:
As Sister who works for the trust I feel very uncomfortable leaving this review.  But feel if issues are not highlighted then improvements will never happen.

My father was an inpatient on ward 21 last weekend.  He is 78 yrs old and has never been an inpatient.  He was brought in via A&E Saturday morning and transferred to ward 21. He was frightened, alone and in your care. 

 On arrival he said he was placed in a dirty scruffy room where the bed not made and was offered no lunch. He was was made to make do with “toast” .  Later in the afternoon I dropped off for him his overnight bag along with a sandwich and refreshments as he was hungry and thirsty.  Teatime arrived and meals delivered but there was nothing for my father.  The staff had forgotten about him.  When staff alerted by him he was offered “toast” once again! Rightly so my father declined and requested a hot meal and said he was hungry!  With great reluctance and rolling of eyes  the nurse said she would “see what she could do” .  Apparently a meal did arrive eventually which he couldn’t eat as it looked and tasted disgusting. 

The following day  I telephoned the ward requesting an update on my father.  The HCA took my number and nurse looking after him never had the courtesy to call me back.  He was eventually moved to a bay following day and the HCA that helped move his belongs apparently put his fingers on the inside of the plastic water cup and his cup of tea ??? My father didn’t want to make a fuss and said nothing.

 I rang the ward once again the following day for an update - message was left but yet again the nurse never rang me back.  My father was finally allowed home after 4 days.  He phoned me in the morning to say he was waiting for a final Doppler test then if that was clear he could come home.  Good enough everything was clear and he was given a 90 min window for TTO’s (meds to take home). I arrived promptly after 90 mins and pharmacy had not arrived - after 45 mins waiting my father told me that he had not been given any fresh water since the day before either and I saw the empty jug and plastic cup on his bedside table.  Eventually  the pharmacist arrived with her trolley full of meds. Annoyingly  My father’s medication was missing from the order! The nurse told me that she didn’t know how long it would take and asked me to call back for it.  I requested it to be sent to Chorley but that was dismissed as she said it was in progress at RPH.  These are critical drugs that my father needed to take before 8am. Which meant I had to make the journey from Chorley to RPH by 07:30 .  

All in all I feel upset that the trust has let my father down.  When I nurse I nurse my Patients as if they are my family members.  Where were the 6 c’s and trust values ???  Yet again the discharge process failed.   Come on LTHTR - the high standards in ward 21 that once was have certainly slipped.

readBy.name: Lancashire Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Appointments
body:
Today I called the surgery and was told that I was 2cnd in line. This was at 15:10 hrs and by 15:40 hrs I was first in line. Further 10 minutes passed and still no answer. How on earth can one caller be on the line for that amount of time. It did occur to me that the practice was closed but I dismissed that thought as I had moved to first in line but I decided to stop my call having been waiting for 50 minutes. This is unacceptable at any time but as there is no alternative practice available we have to accept Hobsons Choice.
Were it not for the very good doctors then I for one would move to Dunmow for my treatment of health problems which are numerous.

title: No empathy
body: Visited / rang this surgery to inform them of the passing of my mother , and a query on what to do with her no longer required medication.... the receptionist attitude was nothing short of appalling... no respect, no condolences or empathy.... urgent need for some training/ people skills in this area .

title: No Appointments
body:
I rang to get an appointment on 30th March - I called at 8am and by 8.05am there were no appointments left, I was told to ring the 7 Day Access number, their first telephone appointment was 6.30pm on 31st! Saw a doctor there who sent me to A & E went through A & E then another clinic to be told that the cause of my problem was something else and I should contact my doctor - guess what I rang at 8am this morning 6th April and no appointments!
I have been registered with this practice for over 20 years and I think its time to find a practice where I can actually see a doctor when I'm in pain and need assistance.

title: AVOID
body: The fun starts when you arrive - two different windows in the same building, for two different GP practices. God knows why - perhaps it generates more cash that way. Patients endlessly passed between the two windows, then when it is finally established you were indeed at the correct window to start with - you are told your appointment (which had already been rescheduled by the surgery once) was in fact a telephone appointment - contrary to what had been booked on the phone and what was displaying in the NHS app, which showed an in-person appointment at the surgery. A wasted trip - and I suspect they won't phone anyway - given it is now well after the supposed appointment time. Avoid this practice - unfortunately I can't comment on the quality of care as I have so far been unable to see a doctor.

title: Phones constantly engaged
body:
I have been trying to book an appointment to see my GP at this practice. The phone line is constantly engaged (after an extended recording of why they don't want you phoning). So I tried visiting the reception to book an appointment, but was refused ... they will only book appointments over the phone.
I can only assume that ongoing medication is no longer required.

title: Started great but ...
body:
I have an extremely distressed and upset 80 year old mum who was due to have her 2nd Pfizer vaccination last week and has not been contacted or advised what the next steps are.  She has had to chase herself and is only told she will be notified - well the 12 weeks are up and there is no reassurance this is ok or that she will receive shortly.  I feel this is totally unacceptable.  My mum has followed all the rules, not gone out, wants the vaccinations and to get back to some kind of normality and has got herself into a state because she doesn't know what's going on.
I absolutely understand there may be supply issues but to not let people know is not acceptable!  It's particularly upsetting as other people I know, who are younger than mum, have gone elsewhere to receive their vaccination and have now had both Pfizer jabs when they received their first several weeks after mum.
I absolutely think the first rollout was marvelous and done so well but this 2nd roll out isn't!

author: thubantd66
title: Lack of support
body: The person who I spoke to from Breathing Space had an unhelpful tone and appeared disinterested, poor at making quick rapport leaving long gaps of awkward, not therapeutic, silence. Repeatedly said they did not understand what I was talking about, it made me not want to disclose any further after the poor attitude and a very unwanted comment that I actually went back around to because I was very taken aback by it. No sympathy or empathy, I always show people this with comments such as ‘I’m sorry this is happening to you’ ‘that sounds like it was very hard’ etc. I didn’t want comments filled with attitude or advice, which is what the website said I wouldn’t get, I wanted someone to actively listen and say ‘what an awful time you’re having, you’ve done well getting though it’ or something of the likes that’s encouraging, open and therapeutic instead of being asked to call back when I "know what I want to talk about". I did want to talk which is why it took me 40 minutes to call in the first place. I was taking my time and was continuously interrupted with comments and they then lead the conversation way of course to the point I felt very uncomfortable discussing my stressors (the reason I called which I never got to) with them. Very disappointed and left feeling worse, I’ve never experienced something like this, especially when distressed.

author: abbdopain
title: Great A&E Care
body: I want to thank the staff in A& E for the excellent care I recently received. Special thanks to Anup, Andy and student nurse Linda, you were all very caring.

author: Halstead Resident
title: Excessive Coronavirus swabs
body: I was taken to the Emergency Department at Colchester General Hospital and I consented to a Coronavirus swab; it was uncomfortable but not dreadful. Two hours later, two different nurses brought new swab packs and both wanted to do it again. I thought they must be training. I said it was recently done. On the basis that it turned out I was being admitted to another ward I agreed to one, but I was very challenged. The nurse was unsympathetic, scratched my throat hard, and I also realised this 2nd test wasn’t logical, so soon.

readBy.name: East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust

author: Halstead Resident
title: A discrepancy between physical and mental health
body: In October 2020 I was attended by three paramedics I was astonished when I gave the required details of my usual meds and was asked if I got them on the black market. Shocked, I reported this and complained. The investigation resulted in every one of the 3 paramedics saying they forgot! It was said in writing that they knew my peace of mind was harmed and also wrote to say compensation is normally payable where there is harm. However, in my case, they refused to offer any compensation.

readBy.name: East Of England Ambulance Service NHS Trust

author: Boat to
title: Ambulance crew
body: My brother-in-law was very sick last night and needed to go to hospital urgently. The paramedics arrived, I can't remember their names but one was a young lady and a Gentleman, they worked as a fantastic team together and they were very knowledgeable and put us at ease and did all the checks they should do and looked after him very well with such kindness. We are very grateful to them.

author: Katrin
title: Supported by local people
body:
Moved and slightly in awe of the caring and slick operation at John Scott Medical Centre in Hackney. The vaccination centre is set up by the community practice and run by a mix of professionals and local volunteers working together.  
Had the Astra Zeneca jab (non profit making) delivered by nurses and supported by local people giving up their time to help. What’s not to like! Hoping the powers that be take note of what works well as a model and learns from this. Thank you to all involved.

author: Peach12
title: Getting my 1st and 2nd vaccine
body:
Today I had my second covid vaccine and I can not thank all the staff and volenteers enough, it was well organised, lovely and clean and the nurse was kind, patient and thorough
Thank you

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Ge2021
title: Really upsetting attitude
body:
My Husband called this morning to speak to a Dr about his declining mental health. In the last year my has battled covid in hospital in april 2020 and later sepsis and ecoli .  
This morning he came off feeling worse than when he began the call, my husband wants to work but at the moment crippling anxiety is preventing him leaving the house . The attitude from the doctor on the call this morning was really upsetting to him

author: handsetrw59
title: Got my vaccine!
body: Great experience. Lovely people. Very well organized. Spacious and clean. Super speedy. 10/10

author: tangocf79
title: Kindness and compassion from the team
body:
The team (led by Sister McKenna) had been caring for both my parents for over a year before our loved mum died suddenly in June 2020, a heartbreaking and challenging time for the whole family but particularly our dad who has dementia.  
The team, in their continuity, kindness and compassion were also providing care to us as carers and were always available with a listening ear, particularly when we were at our lowest ebb.  
Dad deteriorated and we had to take the difficult decision to try a care home setting that would help keep him safe, the same team continued their care which has been such a constant reassurance for us a family but also to dad when adapting to his new environment and routine.  
The whole team and the Diabetic Specialist Nurse, Patricia, have demonstrated professionalism, exceptional care, compassion, understanding, friendliness and exceptional care at all times. Their genuine care and empathy ripples out to reach my brother and myself and we cannot thank this amazing team enough.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: CM10
title: Attitude of reception staff
body: After waiting according to the rules to book my mother into her hearing test in the Audiology department at outpatients today; I was met by an exceptionally frosty member of staff. After confirming my Mother’s name, appointment time and details, I asked if they also needed to see her letter. The staff member didn’t look up at me or answer, just ticked a list and abruptly said that I couldn't stay in there, only the patient, so I’ll have to wait outside. I said I am Mom’s carer and have escorted her as she’s partially sighted and very hard of hearing so she wouldn’t have been able on her own. I was told in a very sharp tone well you can go now, the nurse will help her. I explained again as her disabilities aren’t obvious. They just shrugged their shoulders and carried on looking at the list. I thought this was unnecessarily rude and uncaring. It can be tricky to communicate through masks and screens whilst trying to assist someone who is also disabled without someone being rude and unfriendly in a place if work that is designed for caring.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

author: Kokopops1
title: Felt dismissed by psychiatry
body: I had a video call appointment with a staff member from general psychiatry Lanarkshire, I felt that this person totally dismissed everything I said, suggested it was just my hormones about the problems I'm having and that I have obsessive compulsive traits but I have to help my self to stop that. When I said that I can't, and I will have to struggle everyday, I was prescribed anti-depressants which they said only work 25 percent, never said what they were for considering it was apparently just down to my "hormones".As a woman I feel like I have not been taken seriously and offered CBT but I said I have had this in the past and it hasn't helped, but they still didn't listen, so then said try self help links like every other person has told me to, I have tried them they do not work, one appointment isn't enough either for less than 50 mins to speak to someone and they just seemed desperate to get off the call. I'm sorry but this didn't help at all and was hardly professional.

author: Emmrd63
title: Very helpful
body: I just want to say that Steve is very helpful and that Dan has also been very helpful in the past. I am glad he is still supporting people at Talygarn.

author: Emmrd63
title: IMCA Service
body: I would like to thank Cal for his help with a long-term move of accommodation decision …we worked very well together…great to get a positive result finally …we got there in the end!

title: Perfect Vaccination System
body: I really must congratulate how well the vaccination system was operated when I visited. I can not fault it. Very efficient, fast, friendly and professional. I am very grateful and hugely impressed.

title: Brilliant practice
body:
Reception always friendly and helpful. Practice has a ring back system which works really well. Have always had very quick response when needing to speak to a doctor. Compared to some practices I have heard about, Sherborne is very efficient, keeping up to speed with modern ways of giving care and the best experience possible to 
its patients.
